Award.AbstractNarration:
The Changing Curriculum, Changing Practice project, led by mathematics educators at the Education Development Center, is studying the impact of implementing a NSF-funded, high school mathematics curriculum that emphasizes mathematical habits of mind. This curriculum focuses on ways of thinking and doing mathematics in contrast with curricula that focus on mathematical topics. The project is studying the development of teachers' mathematical knowledge for teaching and their capacity to align their instruction with the new curriculum. The project includes a moderate level of professional development and the development of valid and reliable instruments to assess teachers' mathematical knowledge for teaching and their instructional practices.

This four-year, mixed-methods study is investigating the conjecture that high school teachers' implementation of a curriculum emphasizing mathematical habits of mind will lead to measurable changes in teachers' mathematical knowledge and their instruction. The investigators are also interested in the relationships among (1) teachers' prior knowledge, (2) their use of the curriculum and (3) the school-level support for implementation. The investigators are studying the implementation of the curriculum by 70 teachers in 12 schools that vary in socio-economic status of the students and geographic location. The research design includes observations of the instruction of a sub-sample of nine teachers to obtain a finer-grained measure of instructional practice. They are developing or adapting existing instruments that measure teachers' knowledge and alignment of instruction with the goals of teaching mathematical habits of mind. Using the Instructional Quality Assessment rubric during visits to the classroom, they are assessing students' opportunities to develop mathematical thinking skills. The use of mixed-methods approaches will allow the researchers to analyze the data from multiple perspectives.

This study is part of a long-term effort to help high school students develop specific mathematical habits of mind. The current study is building on previous curriculum development and also developing insights for future studies investigating students' adoption of mathematical habits of mind. The current project is an important effort to understand the roles teachers play in implementing curricular changes that have the potential for improving student achievement in mathematics. Teachers are the critical bridging agents who connect curriculum and learners. This study will help to explain how teachers' knowledge, teachers' instruction, and teachers' contexts within schools contribute to or detract from the faithful implementation of the goals intended by a curriculum. It will lay a foundation for understanding future efforts to assess what students learn and how they learn it.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mathematical Practices Implementation (MPI) Study (ESI-1019945) at Education Development Center investigated the implementation of a mathematical habits of mind curriculum. The study focused on the CME Project curriculum, a four-year high school mathematics curriculum developed by Education Development Center with support from the National Science Foundation. The organizing principle of the curriculum is mathematical habits of mind, which are the specialized ways of approaching mathematical problems and thinking about mathematical concepts that resemble the ways employed by mathematicians (Cuoco, Goldenberg, & Mark, 1996, 2010).

The central proposition of the MPI Study is that curriculum materials, particularly ones designed with MHoM principles, can serve as a professional learning tool for teachers. High school mathematics is described as the most resistant to reform as traditional models for lesson structure and procedural instructional approaches persist in American classrooms. Yet, findings from case studies on school adoptions of integrated mathematics curricula suggest the process of implementing innovative programs, even when they were not sustained over time, built new capacities among teachers, students, and systems, and left behind a legacy of improvements in mathematics learning.

We set out to study the influence of the CME Project curriculum, and in particular the MHoM approaches, on teachers’ learning. We focused our investigation in the first two years of adoption, when teachers will encounter new or unfamiliar approaches to teaching and learning content. The research questions that guided our work included:

  1. What is the impact of implementing CME Project on high school teachers’ instructional quality?
  2. What patterns are evident in teachers’ fidelity of implementation to the CME Project materials?
  3. To what extent and in what ways do patterns in curriculum implementation relate to teachers’ content knowledge for teaching, teachers’ beliefs, and their school and district context?

We used a mixed methods research design that would take into consideration teachers’ own perspectives and experiences as well as the diverse contexts and conditions in which the study’s measures of implementation fidelity, instructional quality, and content knowledge were collected. Research activities included development and adaptation of valid and reliable instruments to collect and analyze data about the written curriculum, the enacted curriculum, and factors that influence teachers’ implementation of CME Project Algebra 1. 

Findings from our analyses have made the following contributions to the field of mathematics education.

Data on the different ways in which high school teachers use a newly adopted curriculum designed to help students develop mathematical habits of mind. Analysis of fidelity of implementation data revealed variation in teachers’ use of CME Project between the first and second year of implementation (N=24 and N=44, respectively). Significant differences in textbook emphasis by chapter, and higher levels of using CME directly to teach critical lessons suggest that over time, teachers used the textbook more flexibly and intentionally to select and teach content. These findings contribute to the growing knowledge base examining effective curriculum use at the secondary level.  

Empirical evidence on the influence of mathematical habits of mind approaches to learning and teaching, presented in a curriculum, on teachers' instructional practices. Based on our analysis of the highest IQA scores for lesson observations by timepoint (two timepoints/year), teachers who remained in the study for two consecutive years (N=7) exhibited significant increases on several dimensions of instructional quality, specifically the Academic Rigor of Discussion and Teacher Questioning, with high-level Task Implementation approaching statistically significant growth. Analysis of the highest scores on IQA teachers' assignment and student work collections show significant improvement in the number of high-level Task Implementation scores by the second year. Looking at the highest scores by year show that the rigor of teachers' expectations for student learning also significantly increased over time.

Findings on the instructional qualities measured in lesson observations and assignment with student work collections show that instructional improvement can occur in the context of implementing a MHoM curriculum, but time and professional development support are critical. Teachers who demonstrated high-level implementation described developing new mathematical understandings and approaches to teaching concepts, and they reported engaging students in more mathematical discussions and higher expectations for their learning. Teachers who did not demonstrate high-level implementation reported struggling to enact the curricular approaches and features, suggesting that additional content-focused professional development was needed throughout the year.

Examples of the Standards for Mathematical Practices enacted in high school classrooms. Observed lesson videos and student work sets collected from our study provide examples to mathematics educators, administrators, and teachers on how teachers can model and scaffold the CCSSM Standards for Mathematical Practice, which are highly aligned with the mathematical habits of mind, in high school classrooms. 

A robust set of tested instruments and further refinement of a framework for studying CME Project and similar interventions. The MPI Study developed and adapted a set of research instruments to measure key dimensions of curriculum implementation, setting the stage for large-scale research.
